summary: A specific innovative AI approach underway in Africa relating to PrEP and telemedicine is the integration of AI-powered risk prediction models into clinics in countries like Nigeria and Kenya. These models analyze electronic medical records (EMR), behavioral patterns, and community-level risk factors in real time to identify individuals most vulnerable to HIV acquisition. This enables providers to offer PrEP more strategically. Additionally, telemedicine platforms in these countries allow clients to start and manage PrEP through video consultations, app-based self-screening, and pharmacy pick-up options. AI is also used to forecast medication demand, reducing stockouts and ensuring a stable supply of PrEP at decentralized locations. Together, these AI and telemedicine tools are making PrEP delivery smarter, more inclusive, and more sustainable in resource-constrained African settings.

A specific example of an innovative AI approach underway in Africa relating to PrEP and/or telemedicine is the integration of AI-powered risk prediction models into clinics in countries like Kenya and Nigeria. These models analyze data from electronic medical records (EMR), behavioral patterns, and community-level risk factors, often in real time, to identify individuals most vulnerable to HIV acquisition. This allows healthcare providers to offer PrEP more strategically. Additionally, telemedicine platforms in Nigeria and Kenya enable clients to start and manage PrEP through video consultations, app-based self-screening, and pharmacy pick-up options. AI is also used to forecast medication demand, reducing stockouts and ensuring a stable supply of PrEP at decentralized locations. Together, these AI and telemedicine tools are making PrEP delivery smarter, more inclusive, and more sustainable in resource-constrained African settings.

This allows providers to offer PrEP more strategically. Additionally, telemedicine tools enable clients to start and manage PrEP through video consultations, app-based self-screening, and pharmacy pick-up options. AI is also used to forecast medication demand, reducing stockouts and ensuring a stable supply of PrEP at decentralized locations. Together, these AI and telemedicine innovations are making PrEP delivery smarter, more inclusive, and more sustainable in resource-constrained settings in Africa.

One specific example of an innovative AI approach underway in Africa relating to PrEP and telemedicine is in countries like Nigeria and Kenya, where clients can start and manage PrEP through video consultations, app-based self-screening, and pharmacy pick-up options. In these settings, AI is used to forecast medication demand, helping to reduce stockouts and ensure a stable supply of PrEP at decentralized locations. This combination of telemedicine and AI-driven supply forecasting makes PrEP delivery smarter, more inclusive, and sustainable even in resource-constrained environments. Additionally, AI-powered risk prediction models integrated into clinics in these regions help identify individuals most vulnerable to HIV acquisition, enabling more strategic offering of PrEP. Moreover, AI-enabled chatbots and virtual counselors provide stigma-free education and support, offering private, judgment-free spaces for users—especially young people and key populations—to learn about PrEP, manage side effects, and ask questions. This integrated AI and telemedicine approach enhances access, adherence, and personalized HIV prevention services in African contexts.

One specific example of an innovative AI approach underway in Africa relating to PrEP and/or Telemedicine is the use of an AI-facilitated digital photo capture and result interpretation system developed by Audere, a nonprofit company working in digital health, as part of the ePrEP/ePEP online pharmacy service delivery model in Kenya. This AI system supports clinical officers (COs) in remotely verifying clients' HIV self-test (HIVST) results by:

- Assessing and improving photo quality of the HIVST results by prompting clients to upload clearer photos if necessary.
- Automatically identifying and analyzing test and control lines on the HIVST to assist COs in interpreting results.
- Enhancing quality control by allowing supervisors to review cases where AI and CO interpretations differ.
- Being intentionally tuned to be highly sensitive to faint test lines to minimize false negatives, with COs retaining final decision authority.
- Enabling easier and more accurate interpretation of HIVSTs remotely, facilitating telehealth-based prescription of PrEP and PEP.

This integration of AI into the telehealth and online pharmacy model enhances quality assurance and helps ensure accurate HIV testing, which is critical for safely initiating PrEP or PEP remotely. The AI system was an added feature, not required by local authorities, and represents an innovative application of AI to support decentralized HIV prevention service delivery in Kenya.

Reference: Audere built the AI-facilitated digital photo capture and result interpretation system for HIV self-tests used in the ePrEP/ePEP pilot in Kenya from 2022 to 2024 (see "Program model" and "Role of AI" sections).

A specific example of an innovative AI approach underway in Africa relating to PrEP and/or Telemedicine is the use of artificial intelligence (AI) by Audere, a nonprofit company working in digital health, which developed an AI-facilitated digital photo capture and result interpretation system for HIV self-tests (HIVST) and rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) in Kenya. This AI system supports clinical officers (COs) in remotely verifying clients’ HIVST results by:

- Assessing and improving the quality of photos uploaded by clients of their HIV test results, prompting clients to retake photos if image quality is poor.

- Automatically identifying and analyzing test and control lines on HIV test kits to assist COs in interpreting test results.

- Providing quality control by flagging discrepancies between AI and CO interpretations for supervisor review.

This AI integration enhances quality assurance and quality control in the telehealth and online pharmacy delivery model (ePrEP/ePEP) by making HIVST results easier to interpret remotely, reducing the risk of misinterpretation, and supporting supervisory oversight. Although the AI component incurs upfront development and ongoing technology support costs, it improves test interpretation accuracy and client service quality within the online PrEP/PEP delivery platform in urban Kenya.

One innovative AI approach underway in Africa relating to PrEP and telemedicine is the use of an artificial intelligence (AI)–facilitated digital photo capture and result interpretation system for HIV self-tests (HIVST) and rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) implemented in Kenya’s ePrEP/ePEP online pharmacy pilot. This AI system supports clinical officers (COs) in remotely verifying clients’ HIV test results by:

- Assessing the quality of photos uploaded by clients of their HIVST results, prompting clients to retake poor-quality images up to three times.

- Cropping and enhancing images of the test result window to aid interpretation.

- Identifying and analyzing test and control lines to provide a second opinion on test results, which the CO reviews before confirming.

- Flagging discrepancies between AI and CO interpretations for supervisory review to ensure quality assurance (QA).

The AI is intentionally tuned to be highly sensitive to faint lines to reduce missed positive cases, with fine-tuning performed during the pilot to improve specificity. This approach enhances quality control of HIVST interpretation within a telehealth and online pharmacy model delivering PrEP and PEP services, enabling private, convenient, and rapid access to HIV prevention in urban Kenya. The AI component also supports remote supervision of COs by flagging possible misinterpretations and facilitates monitoring of testing quality, albeit with additional costs for AI development and ongoing support. This AI integration aligns with WHO guidance on AI for health, emphasizing AI as an assistive tool that allows human providers to override AI decisions.

Reference: Audere, a nonprofit digital health company, built and implemented this AI-facilitated system as part of the ePrEP/ePEP pilot in Kenya from 2022 to 2024 (PATH, 2024).

One specific example of an innovative AI approach underway in Africa relating to PrEP and/or Telemedicine is the development and use of an artificial intelligence (AI)–facilitated digital photo capture and result interpretation system by Audere, a nonprofit company working in digital health, as part of the ePrEP/ePEP online pharmacy model in Kenya. This system supports clinical officers (COs) in remotely verifying clients' HIV self-test (HIVST) results by:

- Assessing and improving photo quality of the uploaded HIVST results, prompting clients to retake photos if necessary.

- Identifying and analyzing test and control lines to assist COs in interpreting test results accurately.

- Flagging discrepancies between AI and CO interpretations for supervisory review to ensure quality control.

The AI system was intentionally tuned to be highly sensitive to faint lines to reduce the risk of missing positive cases, and was fine-tuned during the pilot to improve specificity. This AI integration enhances quality assurance and supports telehealth delivery of PrEP and PEP by enabling remote HIV testing interpretation, thereby facilitating safe and efficient online pharmacy service delivery of HIV prophylaxis in Kenya.

One specific example of an innovative AI approach underway in Africa relating to PrEP and/or Telemedicine is the use of an artificial intelligence–facilitated digital photo capture and result interpretation system for HIV self-tests (HIVSTs) and rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) by the Kenya-based digital health company MYDAWA as part of the ePrEP/ePEP pilot study in Kenya (2022–2024).

In this model, clients who self-administer HIVSTs upload photos of their test results via the digital platform. The AI system evaluates the photo quality and interprets the test and control lines to assist clinical officers (COs) in remotely verifying the HIV test results. The AI is tuned to be highly sensitive to faint lines to reduce the risk of missing positive cases, and it flags discrepancies between AI and CO interpretations for supervisory review. This approach enhances quality assurance and quality control in a telehealth context, enables remote HIV testing as part of PrEP/PEP eligibility screening, and supports timely and accurate PrEP/PEP prescription and delivery through an online pharmacy platform.

The integration of AI in this telehealth and online pharmacy model exemplifies an innovative approach that leverages AI to facilitate decentralized HIV prevention services, improve test interpretation accuracy, and maintain high-quality care while addressing privacy and convenience needs of clients in urban Kenya.
